_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: Ammonia Compressors, Condensers, Evaporators, Pumps, Vessels, Piping and Valves, Ventilation Systems and Purging Systems
_prev_prog_3.Description:
The Dairyman's Land O'Lakes facility contains 4 refrigeration system processes which use Anhydrous Ammonia. The largest process at the facility is the Plant 1 & 2 main refrigeration system. The maximum amount of anhydrous ammonia in the Plant 1 & 2 system process is 25,688 pounds. Although the Plant 1 & 2 ammonia refrigeration system is the only process present above the EPA threshold quantity of 10,000 pounds, the facility has choosen to designate all Anhydrous Ammonia refrigeration systems at the facility as Program Level 3 processes and subject to the requirements of the OSHA Process Safety Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals Standard (29 CFR 1910.119). Everything contained in the plant 1 & 2 Main refrigeration system prevention program applies to all 4 anhydrous ammonia refrigeration system processes, with no exceptions. The reportable quantity for ammonia is 100 pounds.

There are two types of cooling systems utilized in the Dairyman?s Plant 1 & 2 Main refrigeration system:  absorption and vapor compression.  In the absorption (or flooded) type system, liquid ammonia flowing from the receiver through coils of a heat exchanger, where either water or glycol are flowing counter currently on the shell side of the coils, is cooled by the liquid to vapor phase change of ammonia as it boils.  The ammonia vapors are then compressed and liquefied in a condenser for reuse.

A vapor compression system consists of four basic components; the compressor, condenser, expansion valve, and evaporator.  The cycle involves two pressures, high and low, which enables the system to produce a continuous cooling effect.  Low pressure vapor is compressed, raising temperatures and pressure levels.  During compression, heat of compression is added to the vapor as the pressure is raised.  At the condenser, the high pressure vapor is liquefied by cooling.  The liquid ammonia flows from the condenser to an expansion valve where its pressure and temperature are reduced.  The ammonia moves to the evaporator where it absorbs heat from a fluid being cooled.  Vaporized ammonia then flows to the compressor suction to complete the refrigeration cycle.
 
The ammonia vapors from both types of cooling systems flow through a liquid accumulator where any entrained liquids are knocked out of the gas stream prior to being compressed.  This prevents damage to the compressors.  The accumulated liquids are pumped back to the receivers.

The Dairyman?s Plant 1 & 2 Main refrigeration system is a closed loop system and designed to run continuously.  When required, the refrigeration system is recharged with ammonia by off-loaded bulk ammonia to the ammonia receivers.  Ammonia is off-loaded through the tanker's flexible hose connected to the receiver's hard piped charge line.  Recharging only occurs when there has been a loss of ammonia from the system.  Under normal operation, these losses result from fugitive sources (i.e., pump seals, valves, flanges) and from routine maintenance of equipment.

Piping and Instrumentation Diagrams;
 
Comprehensive and up to date piping and instrumentation diagrams (P&IDs) for the 4 anhydrous ammonia refrigeration systems are maintained by the Plant Engineer.  

Ventilation System Design;

The facility has three ammonia engine rooms.  The plant 1 engine room ventilation system consists of three air intake areas and two exhaust fans. The plant 3 engine room ventilation system consists of three air intake louvers and two exhaust fans. The plant 4 engine room ventilation system consists of three air intake louvers and two exhaust fans as well.  One exhaust fan in each of the engine rooms is run continuously. When ammonia is detected at a concentration of 300 PPM the detector automatically activates the emergency ventilation exhaust fans. The ventilation system design data is maintained by the Plant Engineer.

Safety Systems;

Ammonia sensors and control panels are installed in each of the three engine rooms and automatically activate the ventilation system and audible /visual alarms inside and outside the engine rooms. A sail switch is provided on each of the engine rooms continuous exhaust fans.  If a fan fails to operate properly, the sail switch activates an audible/visual alarm inside and outside the engine room.

Safety systems design data are maintained by the Plant Engineer.

Information Pertaining to the Hazards of Ammonia are contained in the MSDS for anhydrous ammonia.  The MSDS meets the requirements of 29 CFR 1910.1200 (g).  This information is also provided as part of each Maintenance Departments Ammonia Refrigeration System Standard Operating Procedures (SOP) Manual.

Materials of Construction;

Information on the materials of construction is provided in the facility refrigeration system specifications and on construction drawings maintained by the Plant Engineer.  

Electrical Classification;

The engine room and plant are not managed as classified areas.  The three engine rooms have ventilation systems that meet current ASHRAE ventilation standards, which exempts the engine rooms from being operated as a classified area. Ventilation system design data is maintained by the Plant Engineer.

Material and Energy Balances;

Material and energy balances have been developed for the anhydrous ammonia refrigeration system and are maintained by the Plant Engineer.

Relief System Design;

The facilities refrigeration system anhydrous ammonia relief system is designed in accordance with ANSI/ASHRAE standard 15-2001 specifications and are contained on construction drawings maintained by the Plant Engineer.  
 
Design Codes and Standards;

2001 Uniform Mechanical Code; Chapter 15, Mechanical Refrigeration Equipment

1988 Uniform Fire Code; Article 63, Mechanical Refrigeration Article 80, Hazardous Materials

ASME/ANSI B31.3-1999 Edition; Process Piping

ASME B31.3 - 1999 Edition; 345 Testing

ANSI/ASHRAE 15 ?2001; Safety Standard for Mechanical Refrigeration

ANSI/IIAR2 ? 1999; Equipment Design, and Installation of Ammonia Mechanical 
Refrigerating Systems

IIAR Bulletin No. R1-1983; Good Practices for the Operation of an Ammonia 
Refrigeration System

IIAR Bulletin No. 107 ? 1997; Suggested Safety and Operating Procedures When 
Making Ammonia Refrigeration Plant Tie-Ins

IIAR Bulletin No. 108; Water Contamination in Ammonia Refrigeration Systems

IIAR Bulletin No. 109 ? 1997; IIAR Minimum Safety Criteria for a Safe 
Ammonia Refrigeration System

IIAR Bulletin No. 111 ? 1991; Ammonia Machinery Room Ventilation

IIAR Bulletin No. 112 ? 1998; Ammonia Machinery Room Design

IIAR Bulletin No. 114 ? 1991; Identification of Ammonia Refrigeration Piping and System Components

IIAR Bulletin No. 116 ? 1992; Avoiding Component Failure in Industrial 
Refrigeration Systems Caused by Abnormal Pressure or Shock

CCR, Title 8, Section 458 ? Design and Construction of Ammonia Tanks

CCR, Title 8, Section 507 ? Piping,Valves and Fittings for Liquid and Vapor lines.

Good Engineering Practices;

The Dairyman's facility believes that the anhydrous ammonia refrigeration systems located at this facility are designed and operated following good engineering practices.  The potential hazards associated with these operations have been identified through a formal process hazard assessment and any action items will be addressed in a timely manner.

Written Operating Procedures;

Written Standard Operating Procedures (SOP's) for the Dairyman's facilities 4 anhydrous ammonia refrigeration processes have been developed in accordance with OSHA's Process Safety Management Standard (29 CFR Part 1910.119). The facilities SOP's provide clear instructions for safely conducting activities involved in each covered process, consistent with the process safety information. The operating  procedures include the following information:  

? Steps involved in initial startup; startup after an emergency shutdown or turnaround; normal operations; temporary operations; normal shutdown; and emergency operations and shutdown procedures, including the condition under which shut down is required and the assignment of emergency shutdown responsibilities to qualified personnel.

? Process conditions and operating steps necessary for safe operation.  

? Consequences of deviations and responses to correct or avoid deviations from the process limits for safe operation.  

? Release information, such as the properties and hazards of materials used in the process, precautions to prevent exposures, remedial actions for a release, any special or unique hazards, and procedures for quality control of raw materials and hazardous chemical inventories.  

? Functions of safety systems.  

? Safe work practices, for activities such as lockout/tagout, confined-space entry, line breaking and vessel opening, and control over personnel entering and exiting a facility.  

The operating procedures are readily accessible to the operators and are reviewed as often as necessary to ensure that they remain current.  The accuracy of the procedure is certified annually. 
 
Mechanical Integrity;

Written procedures have been developed to ensure the mechanical integrity of the anhydrous ammonia refrigeration process equipment, including pressure vessels, storage tanks, pumps, piping systems, relief systems, emergency shutdown systems, controls, alarms, and interlocks.  These procedures include the following:

? Tests and inspections to be performed and their frequency;

? Training for maintenance personnel in the above-described procedures and an overview of the process and its hazards;

? Test and inspection documentation, including the date of the test or inspection, the name of the person performing the task, the identity of the equipment, the task performed, and the results of the test or inspection;

? Procedures for correcting deficiencies either:  (1) before further use of the equipment, or (2) in a timely manner when precautions are taken to ensure continued safe operation; and 

? Quality control procedures to ensure maintenance equipment, materials, and spare parts meet design specifications and are properly utilized.

The tests, inspections, and their frequency are on manufacturers recommendations, codes and standards, or good engineering practice.
Presently, the following maintenance activities are conducted:

? The system performance is reviewed during each operating shift and system parameters are logged.  Maintenance personnel walk through the facility three times daily to visually inspect the system.  If anything unusual is noted it is either immediately repaired, or a work order is generated to initiate the repair or modifications.

? Any unusual performance or ammonia odors are promptly investigated by maintenance personnel.  

? Parts are only replaced with their identical components unless authorization is given by the Plant Engineer and a Management of Change form is completed.  

? Copies of equipment information are kept in the Maintenance office.  

? Associates involved in the PM program are trained in the anhydrous ammonia processes and hazards.  The maintenance staff is trained by more experienced staff that is qualified in the maintenance and operation of the equipment.

? Deficiencies are corrected as required to maintain a safe working environment.  Maintenance materials, spare parts, and equipment have been reviewed for compatibility with the anhydrous ammonia processes.

? The facility is insured for fire.  The fire protection system including fire extinguishers are inspected each year.  The boilers are insured and inspected annually by an outside contractor.  Pressure vessels are inspected annually by the insurer.

Equipment maintenance records are kept in the maintenance office.  The records are kept indefinitely.  

Access Control Procedures;

Plant 1 power yard is fenced and gated, access is restricted to authorized personnel. Exterior doors to both plant 3 and 4 engine rooms are locked.

Contractors;

The management of contractors working within the facility is a significant part of the prevention program.  The facility has a comprehensive contractor management program.  The contractor management program begins with an initial screening of the contractor.  Then, maintenance management personnel are assigned to oversee each aspect of contractor management.  The following elements summarize the main points of the facility's contractor management program:

All contractors must supply required information to complete the facilities Contractor Pre-Qualification Checklist prior to being approved for work.

All ammonia refrigeration contractors are assigned an internal manager.

Contractors are required to check in each day.

Contractors are required to follow all facility environmental, health, and safety rules or are subject to dismissal.  Each contract work area is monitored periodically for health and safety compliance by the area supervisor.  

Contractor is escorted to work area the first day and monitored by Dairyman's staff throughout the project.

Periodically during large projects, or at the conclusion of smaller ones, each contractor is evaluated (using a Contractor Safety Performance Evaluation Form) for compliance with safety requirements.  Based upon this performance assessment, a decision is made as to whether the contractor will be permitted to remain on the bid list.

All contract employees working on the anhydrous ammonia system receive a comprehensive site orientation session covering topics contained in the Contractor Orientation Checklist.  

All hazardous work performed by the contractor requiring the completion of permits (e.g., hot work, lockout /tagout, etc.) is conducted in accordance with the facility procedures.  

Contractors must make a verbal report to Dairyman's by the end of the shift, and produce a written report to the Facility Safety Manager of any injuries; vehicle incidents; and incidents involving damage to property, spills, fires, theft, or loss of equipment, prior to the end of the next working day.

Pre-Startup Safety Reviews;

The Dairyman's facility conducts pre-startup safety reviews (PSSRs) on any new or modified equipment or facility to confirm that the as-built installation meets the design specifications. That adequate safety, operating, maintenance, and emergency procedures are in place, and that operators are trained in these procedures before starting of the equipment.


Management of Change Procedures;

The Dairyman's facility has developed modification control procedures to be used when the technical basis of a design and/or the equipment design basis changes.  These procedures apply to any additions, deletions, or modifications to process chemicals, technology, equipment, and operating procedures.  However, these procedures do not apply to replacements in kind (RIK).  

The modification control procedures ensure and document that the following issues are addressed prior to making any change:  

The technical basis of the proposed change,

Any related safety and health considerations,

Any necessary operating procedure modifications,

The necessary time period for making the proposed change, and 

Required authorizations for the proposed changes.

All personnel affected by the change, including contract employees, must be trained in and informed of the change before the implementation of the change.  For changes involving operating procedures and process safety information, the procedures and process safety information must be updated. 

Hot Work Program;

This facility has developed a system for issuing permits for all hot work operations conducted on or near a covered process (e.g., process involving anhydrous ammonia).  The permit (1) documents compliance with OSHA's fire prevention and protection requirements, which are presented in 29 CFR 1910.252(a); (2) identifies the time period authorized for hot work; and (3) identifies the equipment on which the hot work is to be performed.  The permit must be issued before the start of the hot work and must be kept at the site where the hot work will be performed. 

Facility Permit System;

Hot work is any activity within an area that could potentially produce a spark or involve an open flame.  The Hot Work Policy and Permit System  outlines the requirements and responsibilities associated with conducting hot work at the facility.  The facility maintains an effective hot work permit procedure as part of an overall hot work system.  The written program for hot work contains the following:
  
The Plant Engineer, Maintenance Manager/Foreman, Production Supervisor, PSM Coordinator or the EHS are qualified to authorize the performance of hot work.

A list of locations where hot work permits are required (or hot work permits are not required). 

A training program for associates designated to authorize hot work (e.g., maintenance and operating personnel).  This training program includes specific instructions on:

The types of hazards to look for, precautions that can be taken, and locations and situations in which hot work is prohibited; 

The use, calibration, and limitation of lower explosive limit (LEL) monitoring equipment; 

When cutting and welding is permitted;

Location of fire safe areas;

Safeguards used while cutting, welding and using open flame;

Proper use of fire extinguisher;

Understanding of inspection area before and after work completed;

Maintenance of cutting and welding equipment;

Use of Permit; and

Use of combustible gas detection instruments.

Hot work permit applications are available in the maintenance shop.  Approved and/or completed hot work permits are maintained in the office of the Maintenance Manager for one year after the job has been completed.

Incident Investigation:

Dairyman's incident investigation procedures have been developed to investigate catastrophic releases of a highly hazardous chemical in the workplace or situations that could have resulted in such a catastrophic release.  These procedures include the following required activities:  

Initiate the investigation as soon as possible and no later than within 48 hours of the incident.

Establish an incident investigation team that includes:  (1) at least one person knowledgeable about the subject process; (2) other individuals with appropriate knowledge and experience to thoroughly analyze and investigate the incident; and (3) a contract employee, if the incident involved a contractor.

Prepare an incident report for each incident.  This report must include:  

The date of the incident,

The date the investigation began,

A description of the incident,

A description of the  contributing factors, and 

Any recommendations resulting from the investigation.  

Establish a system for resolving the recommendations of the incident investigation team and documenting any resolutions adopted or corrective actions taken.  

Review the report with all affected personnel, including contract employees.  

All incident investigation reports must be retained for five years.  

Facility Program;

An incident is defined as any unplanned event resulting in or that could have resulted in a spill or release of anhydrous ammonia.  The management elements of the facility program include the following: 

All process incidents are formally and promptly investigated.  Each incident is a learning experience that may result in changes in standard operating procedures (SOPs), process safety information, and training programs.  

All incident investigation reports include a means of preventing future occurrence of the incident, and a written follow-up report is prepared.  

All incident investigation reports are disseminated to those who work in or near the incident area, and are reviewed during safety training classes and safety meetings.  

Responsibilities;

The Dairyman?s PSM Coordinator is responsible for organizing an incident investigation team and conducting the initial meeting.  The Dairyman?s Steering Committee and selected employees act as the investigative team.  The PSM Coordinator is responsible for leading the investigation and completing an Incident Investigation Summary Report.

The Dairyman?s Plant and Maintenance Manager as well as the Plant Engineer are responsible for reviewing the Incident Investigation Summary Report.

The manager of the area where the incident occurred is responsible for participating in the incident investigation, fully considering the remedial activities, and accomplishing those activities that are agreed upon in a timely manner.  The manager of the incident area and others with assignments are responsible for reporting periodically on the progress regarding the implementation of recommendations.  

Location;

All incident investigation reports and progress reports are maintained in the PSM Coordinator?s office for at least five years.

_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: Ammonia Compressors, Condensers, Vessels, Evaporators, Pumps, Piping Systems and Valves, Ventilation Systems, Purge Systems
_prev_prog_3.Description:
The Dairyman's Land O'Lakes facility Plant 1 Ice Bank ammonia refrigeration system process contains 7,633 pounds of anhydrus ammonia. Although the Plant 1 Ice Bank ammonia refrigeration system is not above the EPA threshold quantity of 10,000 pounds, the facility has choosen to designate this Anhydrous Ammonia refrigeration system process as a Program Level 3 process and subject to the requirements of the OSHA Process Safety Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals Standard (29 CFR 1910.119). Everything contained in the plant 1 & 2 Main refrigeration system prevention program applies to the Plant 1 Ice Bank anhydrous ammonia refrigeration system process, with no exceptions. The reportable quantity for ammonia is 100 pounds.

Th Dairyman?s Plant 1 Ice Bank refrigeration system is a latent heat storage unit which stores refrigeration in the form of ice. The latent heat storage resulting from the change in state from water to ice is the key
to the success of these units. Large quantities of refrigeration can be stored in a relatively small space. The ice is produced during periods of low demand for refrigeration or electrical energy. It is then used at a later time in the form of 32o F to 34o F cooling water:  The cooling process is the absorption (or flooded) type were liquid ammonia is flowing from the receiver through coils of the Ice Bank heat exchanger, where water is flowing counter currently on the outer tube side of the coils, is cooled by the liquid to vapor phase change of ammonia as it boils. The ammonia vapors are then compressed and liquefied in a condenser for reuse.

A vapor compression system consists of four basic components; the compressor, condenser, expansion valve, and evaporator (Ice Bank).  The cycle involves two pressures, high and low, which enables the system to produce a continuous cooling effect.  Low pressure vapor is compressed, raising temperatures and pressure levels.  During compression, heat of compression is added to the vapor as the pressure is raised.  At the condenser, the high pressure vapor is liquefied by cooling.  The liquid ammonia flows from the condenser to an expansion valve where its pressure and temperature are reduced.  The ammonia moves to the evaporator (Ice Bank) where it absorbs heat from a fluid being cooled.  Vaporized ammonia then flows to the compressor suction to complete the refrigeration cycle.
 
The ammonia vapors from this cooling system flow through a liquid accumulator where any entrained liquids are knocked out of the gas stream prior to being compressed.  This prevents damage to the compressors.  The accumulated liquids are pumped back to the receiver.

The Dairyman?s Plant 1 Ice Bank refrigeration system is a closed loop system and designed to run continuously.  When required, the refrigeration system is recharged with ammonia by off-loaded bulk ammonia to the ammonia receivers.  Ammonia is off-loaded through the tanker's flexible hose connected to the receiver's hard piped charge line.  Recharging only occurs when there has been a loss of ammonia from the system.  Under normal operation, these losses result from fugitive sources (i.e., pump seals, valves, flanges) and from routine maintenance of equipment.

_prev_prog_3.Description:
The Dairyman's Land O'Lakes facilities Plant 3 ammonia refrigeration system contains 2,106 pounds of Anyhydrous Ammonia. Although the Plant 3 ammonia refrigeration system is not above the EPA threshold quantity of 10,000 pounds, the facility has choosen to designate this Anhydrous Ammonia refrigeration system process as a Program Level 3 process and subject to the requirements of the OSHA Process Safety Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals Standard (29 CFR 1910.119). Everything contained in the plant 1 & 2 Main refrigeration system prevention program applies to the Plant 3 anhydrous ammonia refrigeration system process, with no exceptions. The reportable quantity for ammonia is 100 pounds.

There are two types of cooling systems utilized in the Dairyman?s Plant 3 anhydrous ammonia refrigeration system:  absorption and vapor compression.  In the absorption (or flooded) type system, liquid ammonia flowing from the receiver through coils of a heat exchanger, where either water or glycol are flowing counter currently on the shell side of the coils, is cooled by the liquid to vapor phase change of ammonia as it boils.  The ammonia vapors are then compressed and liquefied in a condenser for reuse.

A vapor compression system consists of four basic components; the compressor, condenser, expansion valve, and evaporator.  The cycle involves two pressures, high and low, which enables the system to produce a continuous cooling effect.  Low pressure vapor is compressed, raising temperatures and pressure levels.  During compression, heat of compression is added to the vapor as the pressure is raised.  At the condenser, the high pressure vapor is liquefied by cooling.  The liquid ammonia flows from the condenser to an expansion valve where its pressure and temperature are reduced.  The ammonia moves to the evaporator where it absorbs heat from a fluid being cooled.  Vaporized ammonia then flows to the compressor suction to complete the refrigeration cycle.
 
The ammonia vapors from both types of cooling systems flow through a liquid accumulator where any entrained liquids are knocked out of the gas stream prior to being compressed.  This prevents damage to the compressors.  The accumulated liquids are pumped back to the receivers.

The Dairyman?s Plant 3 refrigeration system is a closed loop system and designed to run continuously.  When required, the refrigeration system is recharged with ammonia by off-loaded bulk ammonia to the ammonia receivers.  Ammonia is off-loaded through the tanker's flexible hose connected to the receiver's hard piped charge line.  Recharging only occurs when there has been a loss of ammonia from the system.  Under normal operation, these losses result from fugitive sources (i.e., pump seals, valves, flanges) and from routine maintenance of equipment.

_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: Ammonia Compressors, Condensers, Evaporators, Pumps, Vessels, Piping and Valves, Ventilation Systems and Purging Systems
_prev_prog_3.Description:
The Dairyman's Land O'Lakes facilities Plant 4 ammonia refrigeration system contains 2,400 pounds of Anyhydrous Ammonia. Although the Plant 4 ammonia refrigeration system is not above the EPA threshold quantity of 10,000 pounds, the facility has choosen to designate this Anhydrous Ammonia refrigeration system process as a Program Level 3 process and subject to the requirements of the OSHA Process Safety Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals Standard (29 CFR 1910.119). Everything contained in the plant 1 & 2 Main refrigeration system prevention program applies to the Plant 4 anhydrous ammonia refrigeration system process, with no exceptions. The reportable quantity for ammonia is 100 pounds.

There are two types of cooling systems utilized in the Dairyman?s Plant 4 anhydrous ammonia refrigeration system:  absorption and vapor compression.  In the absorption (or flooded) type system, liquid ammonia flowing from the receiver through coils of a heat exchanger, where either water or glycol are flowing counter currently on the shell side of the coils, is cooled by the liquid to vapor phase change of ammonia as it boils.  The ammonia vapors are then compressed and liquefied in a condenser for reuse.

During compression, heat of compression is added to the vapor as the pressure is raised.  At the condenser, the high pressure vapor is liquefied by cooling. _exec_summary.SummaryText:
Dairyman's, Division of Land O' Lakes, Inc. facilities Risk Management Plan (RMP) is in accordance with and promulgated pursuant to Section 112(r) of the 1990 Clean Air Act Amendments. The plan conforms to the Draft Guidance Document for the California Consolidated Contingency Plan published by the Governor's Office of Emergency Services and is modeled after the National Reponse Team's Integrated Plan, the "One Plan." The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (USEPA) has delegated implementation authority for this federal program to the California Office of Emergency Services (OES). At the local level, the program is implemented by the Certified Unified Permitting Agency (CUPA). For facilities operating within the City of Tulare, the CUPA is the Tulare County Environmental Health Department.

The Dairyman's, Division of Land O' Lakes, Inc. facilities consist of a creamery, engaged in the production of dairy products such as powered milk, cheese and butter from raw milk. Five (5) separate dairy processing facilities presently exist.
                           
Anhydrous ammonia, a regulated chemical is present above threshold quantities at the Dairyman's Division of  Land O'Lakes, Tulare facility. There are four individually covered anhydrous ammonia refrigeration processes with a total inventory of 37,827 pounds present on-site. The plant 1 & 2 main refrigeration system is the largest process at the facility but due to it's close proximity to the plant 1 Ice Bank anhydrous ammonia refrigeration system (stationary source) both refrigeration systems are conciderd to be one process under the EPA's reporting guide lines. Plant's 3 and 4 anhydrous ammonia refrigeration processes are stand alone systems and both combined contain less than the EPA's threshold quantity of anhydrous ammonia. Although the Plant 1 & 2 anhydrous ammonia refrigeration system is the only process present above the EPA threshold quantity, the facility has choosen to designate all Anhydrous Ammonia r

iryman's facilities accidental release prevention and emergency response procedures to a Hazardous Substance Release are in accordance with and promulgated pursuant to the California State Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response Regulations (CCR Title 8, Section 5192), OSHA's Emergency Action Plan Regulations (29 CFR 1910.38a), OSHA's Process Safety Standard (29 CFR 1910.119), OSHA's HAZWOPER Regulation (29 CFR 1910.120) and the EPA's Oil Pollution Prevention Regulation (40 CFR part 112.7(d)).

Dairyman's facilities general accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps;

Pre-Emergency Planning;

The Dairyman's facility has determined to use a combination of internal and external spill responders.  [Tulare Fire Dept.] will assist in a spill response scenario.  Other agencies, such as, Police, Local Emergency Planning Commission (LEPC), and hospitals have been notified of our plan.

The local Fire Department will visit the facility at least annually to be familiar with the following:

Facility layout:

  ? Names, amounts and locations of hazardous materials stored at this facility.
  ? Locations of hydrants and other water sources.
  ? Location of normal and alternate access roads, gates, fences, etc.
  ? Surrounding building occupancies and land use.
  ? Precautions and tactics for responding to chemical spills and/or fires.
  ? Day and night telephone numbers of the facility operators, physicians familiar with the products, and manufacturers of the products.
  ? Means of controlling drainage at and adjacent to the facility.
  ? Symptoms of overexposure to hazardous substances.
  ? Procedures to follow in case of contact with hazardous substances.
  ? Situations requiring Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) and proper PPE selection.
  ? Means of ventilating the building(s).
  ? Methods of measuring levels of airborne contaminants.

Personnel Roles;

Spill Responders;

Spill responders at the Dairyman's facility are trained to

ented for any future incidents.  

Training

To have individuals participate with the stopping of a release, training to the Hazardous Materials Technician Level is required on all shifts.  Employees will receive an initial 24-hour training and will attend an annual 8-hour refresher training to keep their certification current.

Medical Examinations

Medical examinations and consultations will be conducted on an annual basis for all Spill Team members.  Medical exams should include a complete medical history, physical exam, respiratory questionnaire, pulmonary function, blood work, and urinalysis.  The physician may request additional tests/information.

Personal Protective Equipment;
 
Personal Protective Equipment is provided up to Level A protection to be used in Immediately Dangerous to Life or Health (IDLH) situations.  The equipment will be maintained/tested according to the manufacturers guidelines.

Monitoring;

Upon initial entry, air monitoring equipment (gas meters or sampling tubes) will be use to determine chemical levels.  Monitors are calibrated on a semi-annual basis.

Periodic monitoring will be conducted to ensure conditions have not deteriorated since initial monitoring.

Situations that may require additional monitoring are as follows:

  ? When work begins on a different portion of the site.
  ? When contaminants other than those previously identified are being handled.
  ? When a different type of operation is initiated.
  ? When employees are handling leaking drums or containers or working in areas with obvious liquid contamination.

Emergency Spill Response Equipment;

Emergency Spill Response Equipment is purchased and maintained by the Dairyman's facility. The local Fire Department is responsible for the purchase and maintenance of it?s own equipment.

Emergency Response Plan Updates;

The Emergency Response Plan will be tested, reviewed and amended as necessary on an annual basis.

The plan will also be reviewed and amended if one or more

of the following occurs.

  ? The plan fails to be effective during an emergency.
  ? The team updates general procedures.  This may result from a post emergency meeting.
  ? Emergency phone numbers or contacts change.
  ? There are changes in the amount, type, or location of emergency response equipment.
  ? Plan revisions are identified during drills.
  ? Applicable regulations are revised.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety; 

1. Management systems: Ensure that management practices and worker training give priority to accidental release prevention.

2. Personnel training: Provide the facilities anhydrous ammonia refrigeration maintenance technicians and operator personnel additional task based knowledge and hands-on-training to further enhance their technical skills and knowledge. Develop and implement a training program evaluation process to ensure that the employees received the required level of knowledge and skill that was expected

3. Security measures: Improve facilities security by installing building and cold storage area security systems to minimize the potential for unauthorized activities.

4. Process design: Install additional sensors to allow better monitoring of the anhydrous ammonia refrigeration process conditions. Replace older reciprocating compressors with new more efficient reciprocating compressors.
